title: Extremely High ping
body: I need help desperately. My average ping during the day is roughly 70, which i can work with absolutely no issues whatsoever. However, almost every night around 7pm to midnight, it spikes ridiculously high to around 350 consistent. I have absolutely NO IDEA whats causing it. I have no other programs running and nobody else uses the wifi. I have looked everywhere to find a solution and have not found one since. I doubt it's the internet/modem itself because as I said, it's fine during the day. If anyone could give me any insight on how to potentially solve this problem I would greatly appreciate it.

replies.body:
What's most likely happening here is that your ISP is rerouting your connection to our servers during their peak hours in order to mitigate congestion on their infrastructure. This is actually a fairly common practice for a lot of ISP's, and the way we can check if this is happening is by looking at a traceroute log. I'd like you to use an application called [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/) to grab this log. After loading up the app, simply plug **104.160.131.1** into the host field and start the trace. After 5 minutes has gone by, export your results as text and paste them in a reply to me.

Let me know if you ran into any issues with those steps.

Your trace reveals that your latency issues start just outside of your network, where your connection spikes to **235ms of latency** on the first hop on your ISP's network. Your latency then continues to rise and fluctuate in the 500s to 700s until you hit our servers. I strongly recommend reaching out your ISP's tier 2 support with these traceroutes so they can look into this for you.

Well that's unfortunate :/ I've already had a conversation with Verizon (my current Internet provider) a few months ago asking to upgrade, and it seems there's no way to have a faster connection without bleeding me dry. Is this the only viable solution?

To be clear: You don't need to upgrade any of your equipment to fix this. You'll need to give the trace information your provided me to your ISP's technical support team so they can investigate the points in the trace that show issues along their own network infrastructure, not yours. If you have any further concerns, please let me know.

TL;DR Your ISP is having some issues on their side, give them this trace so they can fix it.
